Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 2c9efc3cb140e5c1d4d57b73f0a511880ac7a11f
I would expect for testing, PATCH, GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE tested. (e.g.  added a user (POST), Verified the new user created (GET), updated the user's permission (PATCH),  deleted the user)

Yep.  I think ServiceValidator Covers GET and POST.  I need to see what we have that actually takes PUT, and PATCH.  Redfish-protocol-validator I think tests the rest, except for PUT, but I'm not sure where we use that.
Any luck running some basic GET/POST/PATCH from webui-vue? Or like the RedfishValidator and Service Validator ? This looks straightforward enough.. So I think I am okay with unit testing only

Edward ran service validator in the top of the chained commit.


Edware, could you add a sentence mentioning this?
I have done Redfish Service Validator in future commit, will add to commit msg
This fails silently if |verb| is nullopt, is that what we want?
Yes, that's what I intended, unless someone proposes other behavior they'd like to see.
Please write a unit test for this.
???? For an enum?  I'm not sure how to write a unit test for an enum.  Can you be more specific?
Could you write tests for httpVerbToString / httpVerbFromBoost ?

> Could you write tests for httpVerbToString / httpVerbFromBoost ?

Yes, this is what I meant.
I can do that (and I'm happy to), but that's not the line the comment was left on.

I can reword,

"Please write a unit test for this file"
As a general rule I don't think string_view output parameters are recommended given the subtleties in rvalue semantics.  Is there something in the coding standard you're referencing that says that?

I didn't say string_view are preferred anywhere as output parameters. 

These are string literals with static storage. There is an example below.

https://abseil.io/docs/cpp/guides/strings#string_view

Does string_view save a temporary string construction when you do 

```
if (httpVerbToString(HttpVerb::Delete) == "DELETE")
```
Right, I get it.  I'm just looking for reference in the coding standard where it says that's preferred.

Talked offline and it dosent make sense to do with all 32 boost verbs.
Done below though
+1 to Edwards comment.  It doesn't make sense in this case to enumerate all the verbs that WONT be applied.
Is this comment needed? HttpVerb::Max will fall in default, right?
This is the avoid the usage of default. I want to alert the programmer if they add a new HttpVerb. Using default might obscure this required change if needed.

"Done" is typically used for "made a change to address the comment". 
I am still struggling here, it is unexpected code and IMO the name confuses, it named Max but is used for "Not Found"

Apologies, this was accidental on pressing "Done". Are you confused on why I use a case for Max or are you confused on why Max is the name for the last enum?

Using case for max:
I want to use max to be a case statement here so that if other HTTPVerbs are added, it forces the programmer to add a case here or else it wont compile

Naming for max:
I talked with Ed on this one and he said that "max" means "the highest value in this enum", It's used when doing comparisons against containers.

If it was something else, could you clarify further?

Thank you!

It's only used as "not found" when used within the router bitfield, and that's arguably just coincidence.  When used directly within this, "max" will never mean not found, because not found isn't a verb.

I'm ok with this usage, because if we took it out, we would fail some clang-tidy checks, even if the code looks a little odd, I think it has the intended effect.
For next time, both authors should have a signed-off-by :)
Still struggling a bit with this HttpVerb::Max, other than that looks good. 🤷

FWIW, I'm not in love with the data structure there.  I needed something to declare the "right" size bitmask to set.  We could arguably make a custom struct and propagate it, but at some point we're just rewriting the Router class (which arguably could happen at some point).
I'm good with this as it stands.
I guess this was here before..
Yeah notFound wouldnt make sense as a Verb, because it isnt an actual http method that can be used in requests
Lets keep following up in the other comment.
